Soto tells John Bueno in this issue of PULP that the collages are more meditative. item.title: Southern Colorado From Space
item.description:
Southern Colorado From Space

Have you ever seen Colorado like this? "The Colorado front range at night - Fort Collins, Denver, Colorado Springs and Pueblo shining bright." From astronaut Kjell N. Lindgren onboard the International Space Station on December 5, 2015.

item.title: See the US Welcome Millions of Immigrants Over 150 Years In this Interactive Map
item.description:
See the US Welcome Millions of Immigrants Over 150 Years In this Interactive Map

Perhaps the best way to prove that the US is indeed a country of immigrants is to watch the data speak for itself in this beautiful interactive map. Starting in 1850, the foreign-born population swells in the US, first from European countries, then Mexico and Central America, and in the last decade, dozens of Asian countries.

item.title: Pueblo receives two art grants to complete projects - PULP
item.description:
Pueblo receives two art grants to complete projects - PULP

The Pueblo Arts Alliance was awarded $10,000 for unified signage throughout the Creative Corridor, which stretches from Main Street to Union Ave. and up to the Mesa Junction. The Sangre de Cristo Arts & Conference Center received $20,000 to support an exhibition of photographs by artist Ansel Adams. The 2016 annual fall grant awards were announced today.

item.title: This student's sexist Yik Yak comment about #blackwomenmatter just got him suspended
item.description:
This student's sexist Yik Yak comment about #blackwomenmatter just got him suspended

When Thaddeus Pryor saw a Yik Yak message that said "#blackwomenmatter," he responded: "They matter, they're just not hot," according to the Colorado Springs Gazette. The Colorado College student later deleted the post from the anonymous messaging app, he told the College Fix. "I was ashamed, because some people were clearly upset," Pryor told the website.

item.title: The economic promise of Pueblo chile - PULP
item.description:
The economic promise of Pueblo chile - PULP

Is that chile you're eating really a Pueblo chile? Pueblo County Economic Development Director Chris Markuson wants locals, and eventually consumers across the country, to ask that question as the Pueblo chile grows in popularity. The question will hopefully be the result to a three-year strategic plan to build the brand around the Pueblo chile.

item.title: Where Are the Hardest Places to Live in the U.S.?
item.description:
Where Are the Hardest Places to Live in the U.S.?

Annie Lowrey writes in the Times Magazine this week about the troubles of Clay County, Ky., which by several measures is the hardest place in America to live. The Upshot came to this conclusion by looking at six data points for each county in the United States: education (percentage of residents with at least a bachelor's degree), median household income, unemployment rate, disability rate, life expectancy and obesity.
